grammar_tables.title: Development of nominal endings from PIE to Latin
grammar_tables.description: Note "(<)" abbreviates "(fused with last stem sound (consonant or vowel))", "(<<)" abbreviates "(fused with last stem vowel + consonant)", "(–)" abbreviates "(previous vowel is lengthened)", "?(x)" means "possibly x", "(x|y)" means "either x or y".

grammar_table.title: Late Proto-Indo-European (simplified)
grammar_table.description: This table omits the dual number, of which the development of Latin retains few if any traces. Not depicted, but part of Italic development: Pre-laryngeal e-ablauts were already laryngeally colored (i.e. phonetically eh₂ has become ah₂, and h₂e h₂a; p. 63; p. 244; p. 29; p. 42-50). Variations in athematic root/stem accent/ablaut are mostly ignored except for a few cases where stem ablauts easily fuse with the endings proper (i.e. i- and u-stems). Regarding consonant-stem singular nominatives, most scholars assume an -s ending, and for that -s ending to be dropped (with compensatory lengthening of the preceding vowel) after non-stops. p. 186 though assumes the opposite, consonant-stem nouns originally ending in -∅, with -s only copied over later from the o-stem nouns. For stems ending in -n- and -(d|t)-, the stem-final consonant may have dropped too, with any subsequent -s only kept in the latter (example *kwō from *kwon-: Beekes p. 194, Sihler p. 100, 230; example *pōs from *pod-: Sihler p. 130, 280; not depicted: Sihler p. 280 assumes for *pod- that the dental stop was later analogically restored, with the lengthened vowel kept: *pōts .) The accusative plural endings in -ns probably result from suffixing the plural nominative -s to the accusative singular -m ( p. 2084; Meier-Brügger p. 295). Not depicted: a thematic singular genitive in -os, only to be found in the Anatolian branch (Klein/Joseph/Fritz p. 2086), with -os?(i)o probably an early import from the pronouns (Beekes p. 213); an alternate athematic singular locative without ending (Sihler p. 248, 253); the u-stem dative singular ending in -i rather than -ei according to Beekes (p. 203), without explanation contrary to all other opinions. An athematic singular genitive/ablative in mere zero-grade ending -s may have been productiv in Italic for the i- and u-stems (with e/o-ablaut grade of the suffix), and is therefore depicted as a possibility, while a possible sibling for the consonantal stems is not depicted, since it only shows traces in other branches (Klein/Joseph/Fritz p. 2086).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Late Proto-Indo-European eh₂ (feminine) declension
grammar_table.description: Possibly after the split-off of the Anatolian branch, an explicitely feminine declension emerges, marked by a -eh₂- stem suffix to which athematic endings are appended ( p. 189; p. 132-133; p. 323-324, 334-335, 421; p. 131; p. 245, 266). The singular vocative is a special case, with different theories about its form and the logic behind it.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Late Proto-Indo-European bʰ/m-branching
grammar_table.description: In the Italic branch (among others), the endings starting in either -m- or -bʰ- generalize the latter.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic loss of laryngeals, and Proto-Indo-European laryngeal coloring
grammar_table.description: The laryngeals disappear. Vowels neighboring lost laryngeals are left in their phonetic laryngeal coloring (i.e. -e- as -a- when neighbor to -h₂-), and lengthened if the lost laryngeal came after and was word-final or followed by a consonant ( p. 149-150; p. 9-10; p. 63-64; p. 244; p. 28-30, 56-57; p. 42-50). Word-final post-consonantal laryngeals (maybe even after -u: Meiser p. 147) become -a (Sihler p. 99; Meiser p. 107). From these changes, vowel neighborships -aa- (a-stem dative singular), -āā- (a-stem instrumental singular) and (possibly with the a-stem genitive/ablative singular) -ao- emerge that contract to -ā- (Meiser p. 87-88; Sihler p. 83). Post-laryngeal continuation of former eh₂-stem singular instrumental ending -eh₂bʰi is not directly discussed in the literature, but would have given -ābʰi by these rules. The a-stem singular vocative form reflects no single rule path, but an uncertainty that fits the variety of theories about its original form. The i/u-stem singular instrumentals in -ī (<) and -ū (<) are not directly attested for Italic, but are the logical result of the above rules also found in Vedic and Avestan and speculatively included here as such (Fortson p. 116, Sihler p. 312, 323).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic fusion of (dative-)ablative and instrumental
grammar_table.description: Ablative and instrumental fuse to the new ablative ( p. 14-15; p. 281; p. 128; p. 252-253, 258), in the plural together with the formally already identical dative (Meiser p. 128-129, Sihler p. 264): The o-stem instrumental plural ending -ōis replaces the dative/ablative ending. The a-stem dative/ablative plural ending is re-shaped after the result to -āis. In the singular, the pattern of the o-stem ablative ending -ōd is generalized to most other stems. (There may have been an intermediate stage where the singular instrumental endings -ā, -ī, -ū replaced the old ablative endings not as distinctive as -ōd, and were then re-shaped by mere addition of its -d.) Whether this pattern extended to the consonantal stems as -ēd is questionable ( p. 202, 238 vs. Meiser p. 138; Sihler p. 285 tentatively proposes the possibility of a continuation in mere instrumental -ē without final -d).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic influence of Osthoff's Law
grammar_table.description: As per Osthoff's Law, long vowels before resonants are shortened if the latter are followed by consonants ( p. 75; p. 58).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic (sound) changes to the plural athematic ablative/dative
grammar_table.description: The voiced aspirate -bʰ- in medial positions transforms to the voiceless labiodental fricative -f- ( p. 139-141) or the voiced bilabial fricative -β- ( p. 101-103; p. 51-52; p. 149-150; p. 744-745). An -i- that follows this sound in some Indo-European branches disappears in Proto-Italic (Klein/Joseph/Fritz p. 2088).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic vocative losses/merges
grammar_table.description: In the athematic stems, the singular vocative disappears/merges with the nominative ( p. 283, 316, 322; p. 138-139, 147). Latin "Iuppiter" preserves a trace of the endingless u-stem singular vocative, as composite of vocative *dieu with *pāter (Meiser p. 138, 144; p. 200).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic assimilation of e to o before u
grammar_table.description: Before u, (short) e becomes o ( p. 40, 56; p. 59; p. 746). The u-stem plural nominative/locative in -oues is here depicted as the regular result, although Sihler p. 325 states: "for some reason, that is not generally regarded as likely."

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic contraction of -eie- to -ē-, and -ēi to -ei-
grammar_table.description: The singular i-stem dative ending in -eiei is contracted to -ei, either by haplology ( p. 139, p. 187), or by a regular Proto-Italic loss of intervocalic -i- ( p. 188; Meiser p. 91; p. 747) shortening -eiei to -eei, which regularly becomes -ēi (Sihler p. 83, Meiser p. 87), then -ei. Loss of intervocalic -i- would also explain the development of the i-stem nominative/vocative plural ( p. 102, Szemerényi p. 187).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic plural ablative/dative/locative
grammar_table.description: In the plurals, dative/ablative and locative fuse to one common form per stem. In the a/o-stems, this form is identical to the plural dative/ablative's original form. In the o-stems, the result of -ois would have been equal to the locative ending -oisu on loss of its -u ( p. 74), which may have happened at the same time. This formal identity between dative/ablative and locative may have spread to the other stems. The extension of the athematic dative/ablative to the locative is barely speculative (Meiser p. 129 "mag verwendet worden sein") and therefore not depicted.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic a-stem plural genitive
grammar_table.description: The a-stem plural genitive ending is re-shaped after the respective pronoun form.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic u-stem singular dative
grammar_table.description: A u-stem singular dative in -ou appears, either in analogy to the i-stem ending (-ei to -ou: p. 323; p. 251; p. 146; p. 146; p. 761), or derived from the locative (Sihler). (Note that Meiser and Bakkum seem to see this ending as older than -ouei or -uei, with the latter modelled later after the consonant-stem endings.)

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic or later i/u-stem neuters
grammar_table.description: The i- and u-stem neuter plural ending is re-shaped analogically to the either the o-stem ( p. 317, 326) or the consonantal stem ( p. 144, p. 146-147) neuter plural ending; alternatively, according to Meiser (p. 147), the u-stem might have just continued an original -ua ending. The plural change seems (Proto-)Italic (Meiser p. 144, p. 243, 252, Sihler p. 317, 326), less clear is the distribution beyond Latin of a (slightly controversial, see Meiser) u-stem singular in -ū, which may have been influenced by the original plural neuter before that got replaced in this step (Meiser p. 146; p. 760; Weiss p. 252; Sihler p. 323).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Emergence of the ē-declension between Proto-Italic and Early Latin
grammar_table.description: The declension of some words with stems in -eu- and -ei- merges into its own dedicated declension, with stems ending in -ē-. The clearest influence is Proto-Indo-European *dieu-, which by Stang's Law had a singular PIE accusative *diē-m (rather than *dieu-m); this diē- was generalized as a stem to the singular nominative and beyond ( p. 143-144; p. 253-254; p. 337-339). Similarly, i-stem *reHi-, after laryngeal loss *rei- or *rēi-, would, through loss of intervocalic -i- before endings starting in a vocal, produce a new stem rē- (Meiser p. 148; Weiss p. 254; Sihler p. 340-341). Some Italic forms other than Latin would make sense as parts of an ē-declension, but the evidence there is far from abundant or clear (Sihler p. 342; p. 147; p. 761, 763), so the declension's emergence should lie somwehere between Proto-Italic and first epigraphic attestations of its peculiarities in Latino-Faliscan around the 3rd century BCE. The earliest stages attested or assumed keep the regular endings of the athematic declensions, though possibly contracted (singular dative and genitive, plural nominative), or show analogy to a-declension endings with -ā- replaced by the stem's -ē-. Plurals are barely attested beyond rēs and diēs, and except for the nominative explained (Sihler p. 343) as analogies to other declensions, perfectly so by much later stages of those than what is highly speculatively depicted here.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: The o-stem singular genitive from possibly Celtic to Latino-Faliscan
grammar_table.description: Proto-Indo-European -os?(i)o is continued as -osio possibly even into Archaic Latin ( p. 132-134; p. 133-145; p. 222). An ending -ī of uncertain origin replaces this in Latin, but also turns up in Venetic (which, if part of the Italic family, split off from it early; p. 25; p. 127, 465-466), Faliscan, and even Celtic languages. This may continue a Proto-Italic or even Proto-Italo-Celtic ending. Or it may be the result of more recent morphological borrowing between languages in close contact on the Italian Peninsula ( p. 32). The -ī ending may continue a suffix -iH that marks familial affiliation (Beekes p. 212; p. 333; Meiser p. 135).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic or Proto-Latino-Faliscan vowel shortening before -m
grammar_table.description: Long vowels before -m are shortened ( p. 78, p. 77). The chronology is disputed. The shortening is shared with Celtic and Slavic, so might be early; but regular sound change would then have turned endings in -am into -em (Sihler p. 65). There is also evidence for -ām in Italic Oscan. Meiser (as do p. 233; p. 755-757) opts for a late change, while Sihler explains away outliers to the expected development from an early change by leveling / influence from other endings that contain -a- (in Latin) or -ā- (in Oscan). Weiss p. 224 proposes a later shortening happening independently in Sabellic.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Latino-Faliscan thematic plural animate nominatives/vocatives
grammar_table.description: The o-stem plural animate nominative is replaced by the respective pronoun ending (contrast with Sabellic, which went the opposite way: p. 261). The a-stem plural animate nominative is re-modelled after this influence, although the -ās form is still used rarely in later centuries. Sihler p. 271 calls these usages "inherited", but they only seem to show up relatively late and might therefore be ( p. 235) Sabellisms or even mere confusions with the accusative.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Latino-Faliscan addition of -e- before syllabic nasals
grammar_table.description: Syllabic nasals turn into nasals prefixed with an -e- (in Sabellic maybe with an -a-: p. 65; p. 277; p. 96; p. 94-95).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Latino-Faliscan and Early Latin i- and u-stem singular genitives
grammar_table.description: For both i- and u-stems, a singular genitive ending is found that may either continue a possible Proto-Indo-European -(e|o)s ending for these very same stems that would have existed alongside the -(e|o)is and -(e|o)us endings, or import the identical consonant-stem ending. In the u-stems, this ending is merely appended to the suffix. In the i-stems, the e-grade may either have replaced the stem-final -i- to -e-s, or ( p. 316-317; questioned by p. 245) syncopated from an intermediary -i-(e|o)s to -i-s.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Latino-Faliscan or Latin-only convergence of endings in -a/-ā
grammar_table.description: All previous endings in -a and/or -ā converge to -a. The paths to this differ between and . For Sihler, endings in -ā at first prevail over endings in -a (a-stem singular vocative turns to -ā under the influence of the nominative (p. 268), and the consonantic plural neuter under the influence of the o-stem (p. 263)), and later ("[r]elatively late in the history of [Latin]", but "predat[ing] the loss of final -d") all word-final -ā turn to -a, due to "iambic shortening", the influence of the shortened -am ending, or a mysteriously singular vowel shift (p. 78-79, 266-267). Meiser cannot accept such a vowel shift (p. 77) and proposes an inverse generalization of -a endings prevailing over -ā endings (p. 132, 136; see also p. 756; p. 232)). Whether this convergence happened to the whole Latino-Faliscan branch or only Latin is unclear due to lack of vowel-length hints in the available Faliscan texts.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Earliest Latin loss of i- and u-stem singular locatives
grammar_table.description: Earliest Latin loses the i- and u-stem singular locatives ( p. 138-139, 147; p. 245, 252; p. 761), with traces remaining as the adverbs "diū" and "noctū ".

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Earliest Latin sound change of athematic plural dative/ablative
grammar_table.description: The -(f|β)- fricative in athematic dative/ablative endings changes to the voiced bilabial stop -b- ( p. 147; p. 283; p. 101-103; p. 149).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Earliest Latin partial fusion of athematic endings
grammar_table.description: The suffix-ending combination -i-bos, previously found in the plural dative/ablative of i-stems, encroaches upon the consonantal stems (and the u-stems, see below), probably as an import from there. p. 286 though argues that the new ending could just as well be an import from the u-stem: Both -i- and -u- here weakened early to an in-between sound that would only in writing be locked into either -i- or -u- again. In any case, this sound change is deemed the main reason -i-bos now also turns up for u-stems, with -u-bos attested rarely and not particularly early, therefore probably by later analogy or need for differentiation rather than as continuation of original -u-bos ( p. 326; p. 252). More securly, the i-stem nominative/vocative plural ending -ēs encroaches upon the consontal stem, and the previous i-stem singular genitive ending -(e|o)is is completely pushed out by the -(e|i)s ending that is similar to the consonantal ending.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Earliest Latin plural accusatives
grammar_table.description: The various accusative plural -ns endings transform to -s with the preceding vowel lengthened ( p. 215). For the a-stem, this may have happened much earlier – in Proto-Indo-European even, see p. 235-236, p. 133. For a similar interpretation regarding the o-stems, see Meiser p. 136, Weiss p. 206, and p. 2084. On both suggestions, also consider Sihler p. 229, 254.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin loss of -osio genitive
grammar_table.description: The o-stem singular genitive in -osio is barely found in pre-literary Latin (least controversial would be the sparse Lapis Satricanus inscription from the 6th or 5th century BCE), and by the 3rd century BCE seems to be replaced completely by -ī.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin rhotacism
grammar_table.description: By the 4th century BCE, any older intervocalic -s- has become -r- ( p. 95; p. 171-173; p. 150-152; p. 750).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin weakening of diphthongs
grammar_table.description: By the 3rd century BCE, former dipththongs -ai- and -oi- of short length have weakened to -ei- in various inscriptions. The previous state is attested only for the o-stem plural nominative/vocative and ablative/dative – in an old inscription from the 6th century BCE, and the probably similarly ancient Carmen Saliare. That the a-stem diphthongs in the singular locative and the plural nominative/vocative survive this stage (to turn to Classical -ae) seems to affirm their greater length – see p. 235 for a discussion. (Regular PIE outcome for the a-stem singular locative would have been a short -ai at least before some initial sounds of the following words, thus -āi here may have been a generalized sandhi variant; but Weiss also points to an alternate theory by Francisco Villar whereby short -ai may have survived weakening too).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin u-stem genitive singular
grammar_table.description: The u-stem singular genitive exhibits a variety of forms up until the 2nd century BCE. Some continue the u-stem-original -ous and the consonantal-stem-influenced -u(e|o)s (as -uos in the Senatus Consultum de Bacchanalibus 187 BCE, and as -uis in Terence). But in Plautus mostly, and some inscriptions, is found -ī, in analogy to the o-declension.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin initial stage of monophthongization of diphthongs
grammar_table.description: By the 3rd century BCE, short diphthong -ei- probably monophthongizes to a somehwat higher -ē- ( p. 58, 70-72 and p. 101, 143 argue for this; p. 53 allows for it, but calls the evidence "not rigorous"). Less epigraphic evidence is found for a monophthongization of -ou- to -ō- (Meiser p. 49; Weiss p. 103; not argued by Sihler). For quite a while, -EI- and -E- are found to interchangeably represent both the diphthong and the single vowel its monophthongization points to, i.e. EI is even found where -ē- (or later -ī-) would have no ancestry in -ei-; the situation seems to be similar with -OU- and -O-. Furthermore, by the 3rd century BCE at latest, the long diphthong ending -ōi of the o-stem singular dative (still attested for the 6th century BCE) has lost its final glide, possibly (Meiser p. 72-73) due to a generalized Sandhi mechanism. The ē-stem singular dative may have preserved the dipththong in monosyllables ("rei").

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin o-stem plural genitive
grammar_table.description: From the 3rd century BCE on, an o-stem plural genitive in -ōrom (later -ōrum) is attested, which will more and more (but never completely) supplant original -om (later -um). It most probably derives from analogy with the a-declension.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin vowel reductions I
grammar_table.description: By the 3rd century BCE, in closed final syllables, short -o- becomes -u-, except after -(u|v)- ( p. 71, 84; p. 66), and around the same time, short -e- in final closed syllables becomes -i-, except before nasals (Meiser p. 71; Sihler p. 65; p. 138 sees an early example around 350 BCE already).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin singular ablative and the loss of -d
grammar_table.description: During the 3rd century BCE, word-final -d after long vowels is lost in speech, though still used in writing until the 2nd century BCE ( p. 100; p. 155; p. 228). This accounts for most singular ablatives of Classical Latin, except for the consonant-stem ending in short -e. A consonant-stem ending -ED is attested epigraphically in the 3rd century BCE, but may be a false archaism (Weiss p. 238), and no continuation in -ē is found; Classical Latin -e instead is thought to derive from the locative ending in -i, but how and when that might have become the ablative ending remains unclear (Sihler p. 285).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Old Latin later stage of monophthongization of diphthongs
grammar_table.description: Between the end of the 3rd century and the middle of the 2nd century BCE, the monophthongization of former -ei- has (after the possible intermediate stage of -ē-) developed to -ī-, and that of former -ou- to -ū- (after the possible intermediate stage of -ō-). The u-stem plural nominative/vocative ending -ūs may emerge from this with questionable syncope of a previous e-ablaut ending (from -ou-es); an alternate theory is that the accusative ending was used here in analogy to the nominative-accusative similarity among consonantal stems ( p. 146; p. 325-326; p. 124, 252).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: WIP: classical
grammar_table.description: -o- becomes -u- before final consonants ( p. 66), nominative/vocative -ros/-re/-ris becomes -r after vowels (not for i-stems) and -er after consonants ( p. 70), vocative -ie and genitive -iī become -ī ( p. 256, 260), o-stem nominative plural is replaced from the pronoun -oi becoming -ei becoming -ī ( p. 260), same with a-stem nominative plural ( p. 271), -āi shortened to -ae ( p. 268), in a-stem plural dative-ablative –īs is replaced with -ābus where necessary to avoid homophony with o-stem plural dative-ablatives ( p. 272), word-final -ss becomes -s ( p. 204-205), (former) dorsal stop plus -s becomes -x ( p. 204), final -i becomes -e ( p. 65), consonant locative singular in -ī is modeled in analogy to o-stems ( p. 285), -rs becomes -rr becomes in final position -r ( p. 211), former root stems in -s whose -s- became -r- intervocalic sometimes retain -s in the nominative singular ( p. 310-311), long vowels before final non-s consonants shorten ( p. 79), l-stems emerge from other stem-forms (-n-, -l/n-) ( p. 304), some neuter s-stems (notable exception: root nouns) analogize the rhotacized stem ending (-r-) to the nominative singular ( p. 306, 309) the -on- suffix of consonant stems is reflected as medial -in- ( p. 60-61, 295-296), consonant stem endings encroach on i-stem endings ( p. 318), i-stems in -nd-, -nt-, -rt- end in -s (<<), with lengthening of preceding vowel if -ns results ( p. 316), i-stem neuter nominative/vocative singulars lost their end vowel on mono-syllabic stems ( p. 69), u-stem singular nominative/vocative/accusative emerges somehow ( p. 323), u-stem plural animate nominative/vocative emerges from unknown etymology ( p. 325), certain animate n-stem nouns with nominative singular in -en emerge from gender change, compounds with the weakened root "can-", and unclear etymology ( p.296, 298), long vowels shorten before other vowels ( p. 80), the 5th or ē-stem declension emerges, fusing various different paradigms into one ( p. 340-343). Not depicted: u-stem (or rather: ū-stem) freak cases "sūs" and "grūs" ( p. 328). Not depicted: Freak case "Iuppiter"/"Iovis" ( p. 338-339). Not depicted: Freak case "bōs"/"bovis" ( p. 334-336). Not depicted relationship: animate i-stem nouns with accusative singular in -im always form the ablative singular to -ī ( p. 316). Not depicted: i- and mixed-stem freak cases of "senex"/"senis", "urbs"/"urbis", "nox"/"noctis", and s-stem root nouns with genitive plural in -ium, and the opposite with nominative singular in -is and otherwise consonant-stem endings ( p. 319). Not depicted: kinship nouns of animate consonant stems in -r with nominative singular in -er (<) (like "pater"/"patris") ( p. 293). Not depicted: The consonant stems in -n- freak cases of "carō"/"carnis", "iuvenis"/"iuvenis", "sangu(i|ī)s"/"sanguinis", "liēn"/"li(e|ē)nis", "fel"/"fellis" ( p. 291, 295-296, 298). Not depicted: The consonant stems in -l- freak cases of "sāl"/"salis", "fel"/"fellis", "mel"/"mellis" ( p. 304). Not depicted: The root noun freak cases of "vīs" and "spēs"/"speī" ( p. 311). Not depicted: Neuter r/n-stems freak cases of "femur"/"feminis", "iecur"/"iocineris", "iter"/"itineris" p. 298-299). Not depcited: Nouns in -ēs nominative singular, mostly behaving like i-stem nouns ( p. 316). Not depicted: Heteroclitic nouns that may inflect to more than one paradigm ( p. 344-345). A locative plural in -īs is too speculative ( p. 253 alone mentions it, prefixed with a "perhaps") to include in the table.

declension_def.title: consonant stem in dental and some stems in -r formerly in -s
consonant stem in (former) dorsal (g, c, v, h)
consonant stem not in dental, dorsal, or -r/-n
